title: Compiling with Visual C Command Line

For programmers coming from GCC or Clang to Visual Studio, or programmers more comfortable with the command line in general, you can use the Visual C++ compiler from the command line as well as the IDE.

inline_content.Text: For programmers coming from GCC or Clang to Visual Studio, or programmers more comfortable with the command line in general, you can use the Visual C++ compiler from the command line as well as the IDE.

title: Note that unlike GCC, Visual Studio doesn’t provide a front-end for the linker (
link.exe
c
) via the compiler (
cl.exe
c
), but instead provides the linker as a separate program, which the compiler calls as it exits.
cl.exe
c
and
link.exe
c
can be used separately with different files and options, or
cl
c
can be told to pass files and options to
link
c
if both tasks are done together. Any linking options specified to
cl
c
will be translated into options for
link
c
, and any files not processed by
cl
c
will be passed directly to
link
c
. As this is mainly a simple guide to compiling with the Visual Studio command line, arguments for
link
c
will not be described at this time; if you need a list, see
here
a
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/y0zzbyt4.aspx

title: There are other valuable command line parameters as well, which it would be very useful for users to know:

title: For anyone more familiar with *nix systems and/or GCC/Clang,
cl
c
link
c
, and other Visual Studio command line tools can accept parameters specified with a hyphen (such as
-c
c
) instead of a slash (such as
/c
c
). Additionally, Windows recognises either a slash or a backslash as a valid path separator, so *nix-style paths can be used as well. This makes it easy to convert simple compiler command lines from
g++
c
or
clang++
c
to
cl
c
, or vice versa, with minimal changes.

inline_content.Text: For anyone more familiar with *nix systems and/or GCC/Clang,
, and other Visual Studio command line tools can accept parameters specified with a hyphen (such as
). Additionally, Windows recognises either a slash or a backslash as a valid path separator, so *nix-style paths can be used as well. This makes it easy to convert simple compiler command lines from
, or vice versa, with minimal changes.

title:
g++ -o app src/main.cpp
cl  -o app src/main.cpp

content_resolved.code:
g++ -o app src/main.cpp
cl  -o app src/main.cpp

title: Of course, when porting command lines that use more complex
g++
c
or
clang++
c

options, you need to look up equivalent commands in the applicable compiler documentations and/or on resource sites, but this makes it easier to get things started with minimal time spent learning about new compilers.
